title: Does it Really do Everything They Say?
description:
Background:  I've been using the "Lucas Heavy Duty Oil Stabilizer" for a few years in my old, high mileage SUV which was used only occasionally for towing a boat and for winter storm driving.  It would often sit unused for a month at a time.  When started after a long period of no use, the engine would make a horrible, dry, grating, mechanical noise which I knew couldn't be a good thing.  So, based solely on manufacturer claims, I started using the heavy duty stabilizer.  Much to my pleasant surprise, the nasty gear/bearing noises totally disappeared immediately after my first use of the product and have never returned.
Currently:  I recently traded in the old SUV on a low mileage, gently used one of a different make. When reading up on my new SUV online, I found out that this particular motor has somewhat of a reputation for a rattling, dry mechanical noise upon cold startup which would last until the engine was warm.  It was a sound I heard immediately after the first cold start at home.  It wasn't nearly as bad as the sound from the old SUV, but it bothered me none the less.  I immediately thought of using the heavy duty oil stabilizer, however, my newer car requires much thinner 5-20W oil, and synthetic oil is highly recommended by the manufacturer.  So I bought the "Synthetic Oil Stabilizer" and did a complete oil/filter change and added one quart of the stabilizer.  The next day, the engine fired up and didn't even show a hint of the noise I had heard previously.  Still no noise 2000 miles later, even after a couple weeks of non-use at a time.
When I used the "synthetic oil stabilizer", I noticed it looks and feels totally different than the "heavy duty" stuff.  It's thinner, pours easier, and has a clearer, somewhat milky look to it.
But does it do EVERYTHING they claim it does?  Who knows.  But I do know that it eliminated my dry starts in the newer vehicle.  I've been tracking gas mileage and haven't really noticed much, if any, difference.  But I wouldn't expect much improvement on a type of car that doesn't get great mileage to begin with.
Why only 4 stars?  The only way to know if the stuff does EVERYTHING they claim, would be to track mileage over a long period of time, do a complete engine tear down, run dyno tests, and compare results with an identical vehicle which didn't get the same oil treatment.  Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be any such tests/comparisons.  I think Lucas could do a much better job of proving their claims than they've done up to this point.  Until I see some kind of proof with a scientific comparison, or when I tear down my engine at 250,000 miles (which isn't going to happen), 4 stars is the best I can do.
However, as I stated, I know it works to eliminate my dry starts.  That's worth 4 stars for me.
I hope some of this is helpful to you.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2013
